another NATO fuel supply convoy was
attacked on Tuesday it's the fifth
attack in a week following Pakistan's
decision to close the Khyber Pass the
key supply line for NATO forces in
Afghanistan Jane perlas reports from
Islamabad in the last five days some of
these trucks have been burned it's not
clear exactly who has burned them but
it's pretty clear that these trucks have
been allowed to be burned as a signal of
huge displeasure and anger by the
Pakistani government at strikes by NATO
helicopters on border posts on the
Pakistan border with Afghanistan there
have been three or four such strikes in
the past week and in one of those
strikes three Pakistani para military
officers were killed and any time a
Pakistani paramilitary or soldier is
killed by NATO American forces it shows
up the huge anti-american sentiment in
this country I think this shows very
clearly the fraught nature of the
alliance between Pakistan and the United
States some people question whether it
is an alliance the United States has
funded Pakistan to the tune of two
billion dollars a year in military and
increasingly in civilian aid and they
have gotten some things in return one of
the things they've gotten in return is
the passage of these vital supplies to
Afghanistan another thing they've gotten
is the off-the-record permission for the
drone strikes but in many ways Pakistan
in the united states have different
strategic goals
and this is becoming clearer and clearer
as the Afghanistan war comes into its

story from tomorrow's business section
Tom Zeller reports from vinal Haven
Maine on a town's love-hate relationship
with their new wind turbines we got an
extension cord going down to the house
there we set up our weather station over
here a sound meter right here several
times a week art lindgren trudges into
the darkness near his home to measure
the sound of three nearby wind turbines
mr. lindgren and his wife Cheryl live on
the island of vinalhaven off the coast
of Maine the turbines were built by the
Fox Islands electric cooperative which
is largely owned and funded by the
thirteen hundred or so full and
part-time residents here they wake us up
at night they're hard to go to sleep too
since then the turbines have become the
center of a bitter controversy that has
rattled this island community and raised
questions about the social costs of
renewable sources of energy like wind we
built this house in two thousand it's a
project that we've waited our whole life
to do we're retired and this is this is
it but for others on this rocky island
the wind project has become a genuine
source of pride I think they look nice
and I think the majority of us like them
the turbines are expected to produce
over 11,000 megawatt hours of
electricity per year I think it was up
to 26 bucks my power bill went down for
a month the controversy here is
emblematic of the challenges that the
wind industry increasingly faces as
turbines are built nearby where people
live part of your plan has to be well
what are we going to do with the people
that it ruins their lives so in theory
everyone loves renewable fuel that all

had hats t-shirts

and there's been some negotiation
